Award.AwardTitle: Investigating the Structural Basis of the Optical and Photochemical Properties of Chromophoric Dissolve Organic Matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
The importance of chromophoric dissolved organic matter (CDOM) to the aquatic light field and the biogeochemistry of both fresh and marine waters has been well established over the last 20 years; however, the structural basis of its optical and photochemical properties remain unclear, particularly for marine waters. Scientists from the University of Maryland will address this issue by a applying a comprehensive suite of optical, mass spectral, chemical, and photochemical measurements to samples (solid phase C-18 extracts and the original waters when possible) collected on a cruise transecting the equatorial Atlantic. Results from this study will be compared with those obtained from fresh, estuarine, and coastal waters of the Middle Atlantic Bight. The complete spectral dependencies of absorption and fluorescence emission will be acquired and compared with the lignin phenol content, the ultra-high resolution mass spectra, relative average size as determined by gel permeation chromatography, and dissolved organic carbon content. Two indices of photochemical reactivity, the photo-production of hydrogen peroxide and the photo-sensitized oxidation of selected phenols, will be further employed to examine how reactivity is affected by structural differences in CDOM collected from fresh, coastal and offshore waters. Changes in the optical spectra, ultra-high resolution mass spectra and photochemical reactivity following treatment with sodium borohydride, a selective reductant of aldehydes, ketones and quinones, will be used to test for the presence of charge-transfer interactions and their possible contribution to the optical properties, as well as to potentially establish unequivocal markers of CDOM source.

In terms of broader impacts, this research would provide new insights on the structural basis for the optical and photochemical properties of chromophoric dissolved organic matter, as well as place constraints on the sources of this material. Two graduate students would be supported and trained as part of this project. It is anticipated that University of Maryland undergraduate students and French undergraduate students from the Engineering School of Chemistry of the Ecole Nationale Superieure de Chimie de Clermont Ferrand also would participate in the study but at no cost to the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to define the source(s) and the structural basis of the optical and photochemical properties of chromophoric dissolved organic matter (CDOM).

 

Over the past decade, the importance of CDOM to aquatic ecosystems has become increasingly recognized. Absorption by CDOM has been shown to contribute substantially to the aquatic light field in both fresh and marine waters. CDOM is also photo-reactive, leading to the production of a variety of intermediates and products and the loss of absorption. These photochemical reactions can play a significant role in the biogeochemistry of surface waters through the formation of compounds that are more readily metabolized by bacteria, the release of bio-available nutrients, and the enhanced penetration of ultraviolet radiation into surface waters. Because of the significant contribution of CDOM to the optical properties of most surface waters, satellite ocean color measurements can, in principle, be employed to follow its distribution and dynamics over broad spatial and temporal scales, ultimately providing information relevant to carbon cycling, the mixing of surface waters, as well as basin-scale biogeochemical processes.

 

Although numerous studies over the past decade have acquired either optical absorption or emission spectra of CDOM from a broad range of fresh and marine waters, few of these studies have attempted to address the structural basis of these optical properties, particularly as they relate to the sources of CDOM to these waters. And, as of today, the structural basis of the optical and photochemical properties of these materials remains largely unknown and is commonly treated as a “black box.” We have proposed an electronic interaction model to explain the optical and photochemical properties of CDOM. In this model, the optical absorption and emission properties of terrestrial CDOM arise in part from intramolecular charge transfer interactions between hydroxy/methoxy-aromatic donors and carbonyl-containing acceptors such as aromatic ketones and quinones formed through the partial oxidation of lignin precursors. This model, that we continue to test, may be broadly applicable to other materials that exhibit broad-band absorption upon partial oxidation, including those found in atmospheric aerosols.

 

Within this project, we selectively altered specific functional groups within CDOM (ie. we reduced carbonyl-containing functional groups with sodium borohydride) and followed the changes in optical and photochemical properties of this material along with changes in CDOM mass spectra. Because CDOM is found ubiquitously in aquatic environments, this research encompassed CDOM from very diverse locales to better define CDOM source(s). We thus (a) investigated and compared the optical properties of CDOM originating from estuarine, coastal and offshore  oceanic locales; (b) investigated CDOM photochemical properties relating to hydrogen peroxide formation and phenol oxidation by CDOM originating from these differing locales; (c) developed and applied a selective mass labeling approach for linking the optical and photochemical properties of CDOM to structure and composition via ultra-high resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry; (d) investigated the effect of pH on the optical properties of CDOM from these diverse locations.

 

All the samples investigated responded similarly to this chemical treatment (borohydride reduction) in terms of changes in their optical and photochemical properties and mass spectra despite their very different origin. This result is extremely important in that it suggests a common origin for this material as well as a common structural basis for its optical and photochemical properties independently of its location.
